name: Kami (Divine Spirits)
shortDescription: Divine spirits or gods that inhabit all things, the central concept of Shinto religion
fullDescription: Kami (Á•û) are the divine spirits or sacred essences that permeate all existence in Shinto belief. The term is notoriously difficult to translate, encompassing gods, spirits, sacred forces, and the divine quality within natural phenomena. Kami can be major deities like Amaterasu and Susanoo, ancestral spirits, natural forces (mountains, rivers, storms), animals, and even abstract concepts. The phrase 'yaoyorozu no kami' (ÂÖ´Áôæ‰∏á„ÅÆÁ•û, 'eight million kami') suggests their countless number. Unlike the monotheistic concept of God, kami are immanent rather than transcendent, dwelling within the world rather than beyond it. Kami can be benevolent or dangerous, peaceful or violent, protective or wrathful. They are not omnipotent or morally perfect but possess specific powers and characteristics. Humans can become kami after death, especially powerful rulers or those who died tragically. The relationship between humans and kami is reciprocal: humans offer worship and purification, while kami provide blessings and protection. Kami respond to ritual purity (harae) and are repelled by pollution (kegare).

manifestations.description: Kami manifest in countless forms: celestial deities in Takamagahara, earthly kami in nature (mountains, waterfalls, ancient trees), ancestral spirits watching over descendants, and abstract forces like growth and decay. Kami descend to shrines when called through ritual and depart after bestowing blessings. They may appear in human or animal form, speak through oracles, or manifest as natural phenomena.

originPoint.name: Takamagahara (mythical) / Japanese archipelago (practice)
originPoint.description: Kami beliefs originated across the Japanese archipelago during the Yayoi period, with major cult centers at Ise, Izumo, and sacred mountains nationwide.

firstAttestation.description: First comprehensive written account of kami in the Kojiki. The word appears extensively in earlier Man'y≈çsh≈´ poetry.

timelinePosition.description: Kami worship emerged in Yayoi period (300 BCE-300 CE), formalized during Kofun period (300-538 CE), systematized in Asuka/Nara periods (538-794 CE), continues to present.
